comments.body: @thockin My gut is to pass `mount.Interface` to all `ProbeVolumePlugins()` functions.  If we start to accumulate other things later we can make a `PluginContext` wrapper for them later.

The counter argument is that some volumes (e.g. PD) provide their own Mounter implementation for "real" code, which is counter to real dependency injection.  The reasoning is that GCE provides a "safe format and mount" script, rather than providing a "safe format if needed" script and leaving mount to us.

I decided to stay simple because the alternative is only slightly more consistent and significantly more churn to implement.  I'm happy to be convinced that it's worthwhile, but I'm not there yet
@thockin cool, agree we don't need the churn for now.  This is fine.
We will need to set the selinux context appropriately here as I've been working on in #5162
We can potentially also add MkdirAll() to Mount() since all current users of it do the same logic.

@pmorie yes, of course.  I just can't test it so I did what I could test, assuming you would decorate it with selinux afterwards :)

@vmarmol we could - I tried to follow the mount() semantics, which does not mkdir because that's sort of a policy thing and better left to a caller.  IMO.
@thockin @vmarmol Agree, Mounter should not mkdir anything
Packages should usually be no underscore, all one mashed together thing (httptest, filepath, etc).  Minor consistency thing, but...
puke, really?  Even for dirs with underscores in their names?  Do we have to follow this?  I find that  sort of obfuscatory

I think the argument is you don't put underscores in the directory name either.  I mean, you can totally do it... But then you're the only one.  So.... :)

> On Jan 18, 2015, at 5:35 PM, Tim Hockin notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> In pkg/kubelet/volume/empty_dir/empty_dir.go:
> 
> > @@ -0,0 +1,126 @@
> > +/*
> > puke, really? Even for dirs with underscores in their names? Do we have to follow this? I find that sort of obfuscatory
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

I don't actually find any guidance from Go people here.  They say "use short names" (paraphrasing) but do not address the case of "so your file name is logically two words".  Can you link me to a reference?

There's at least one other set of files that use underbars in pkg names, and that ALSO has my fingerprints...

I won't hold you to the fire - I just pointed it out.  Consider it a nit.

----- Original Message -----

> > @@ -0,0 +1,126 @@
> > +/*
>

> names" (paraphrasing) but do not address the case of "so your file name is
